subject: Economics
statement_full_text:
Why do you want to study this course or subject?

I want to study Economics because I am eager to understand the deeper reasons behind economic distribution and wealth inequality. Growing up witnessing poverty around me, I came to notice that the fundamentals underpinning our economy were broken. With the escalating cost-of-living crisis driving more families into deprivation, I was left to ask: "If money can be created so easily, why does poverty still exist?". This led me to question the role of debt in shaping the economy.

I explored this further during a work experience placement at the Bank of England, where I was appointed Deputy Lead on a group project on fiat and commodity money. I was fascinated to learn how excessive debt contributed to the housing bubble in 2008, putting many working-class families at risk of financial hardship. This transition to more credit-based economies, resulting from the monetarist policies of the 2000s that dominated in the UK and US, has developed into structures that allow individuals with more resources to accumulate wealth at the expense of those lower down the economic hierarchy. This felt critical to me â€“ the shift from a labour-based economy to one with intensifying rentier capitalism was a key factor driving prices of basic goods up, causing families to rely on food banks.

It is this interdisciplinary nature that draws me to the subject, as I aspire to better understand the issues around economic disparity. Uncovering the challenges working-class families face across the world motivates me to study the subject at a deeper level.

How have your qualifications and studies helped you to prepare for this course or subject?

Studying A Level Economics introduced me to the impacts of financialisation, particularly how it can withhold wealth from the productive economy, marginalising the working class.

Thomas Piketty's work on wealth concentration showed me how, without progressive wealth taxation, extreme wealth appropriation can worsen inequality and restrict the government's fiscal scope. This means appropriation may push governments to rely on a monetary policy such as quantitative easing to stimulate demand. Overreliance often inflates assets and living costs, ultimately deepening the cost-of-living crisis. This led me to discover "Fictitious Capital". Reading this alongside my studies shaped my view that rentier capitalism drives up the value of assets such as housing and land, making them increasingly inaccessible to families. It was particularly saddening to learn that many young adults may not be able to afford their own home, and it made me recognise the need for progressive taxation on assets, rather than just income.

Reading "Why Nations Fail" challenged me to think more critically about the role of governments. While the authors argue that inclusive institutions reduce inequality, I found that both inclusive and extractive bodies can foster exploitative rentier capitalism and hinder the reach of working-class families. Taken together, these readings further motivated me to advance my understanding of wealth inequality at a societal level.

What else have you done to prepare outside of education, and why are these experiences helpful?

To learn more, I attended a work experience placement at the HM Treasury, where I explored how the government is supporting deprived areas in Britain. I was astonished to learn of the positive impact the Darlington Economic Centre has on the town's deprivation, which introduced opportunities and businesses to the North rather than concentrating them in London. Bringing corporations and jobs into the North is crucial in closing the rural divide.

Within my work experience, I presented an idea around a major national policy change, which led me to consider the design of parking fines. While these fines are meant to induce behavioural change, they have a disproportional impact on the working-class while having little impact on the wealthy. Researching Finland's day fine system, where penalties are proportional to income, showed me how fines could help tackle growing wealth inequality in the UK.

To stay informed on the state of the global economy, I regularly read The Economist's Espresso and The New York Times. In addition, my involvement in the Student Union has developed my communication and leadership skills as I contributed to the creation of societies and took part in weekly meetings.

Extension [1200 Characters]

I applied for Land Economy at Cambridge as I would like to explore the complexities of urban economics, which is largely not covered in my A levels. I gained this interest after attending a Masterclass, where I explored how legal and institutional frameworks shape policy outcomes in housing and the socio-economic consequences that follow as a result.

This inspired me to develop a 2D-city building simulation for my Computer Science NEA, illustrating how zoning choices influence GDP, population growth, and happiness. Creating this project showed me how cities must be carefully designed to meet the needs of their residents, growing my passion for urban economics.

I am also drawn to Cambridge's supervision system, as I have always found teaching in small groups more impactful, allowing learning to be closely directed to my own problems and questions. To me, there is a real importance of interacting with peers who share the same ideas and others who hold different perspectives.

feedback_items.your_feedback: This is definitely top 3 personal statements read this season, and probably the best for a contextual student. The statement is very well explained with compelling intro, good holistic understanding, nice insights from books, and nothing repetitive.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Consider which courses and universities are priorities to potentially adjust sections, but overall minimal changes needed.
feedback_items.strong_passage: the intro is actually like pretty compelling. Even considering the fact that a lot of you guys are putting the same sort of stuff in here, I think you've linked it really well because you've brought it straight into debt and it's very academic, really well explained
feedback_items.why_strong: Strong academic focus with clear logical connections from personal experience to economic concepts, particularly debt and its role in the economy.

feedback_items.your_feedback: There's obviously a limit to how much land economy content you can bring in when focused on economics. You have to hope Cambridge cares less and focuses on the interview.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: If applying to a college requiring additional work, the personal statement matters less depending on what you submit.

feedback_items.your_feedback: Good sections with nice insights from books - actually interesting insights compared to other statements that just tend to be summary points.
feedback_items.strong_passage: Thomas Piketty's work on wealth concentration showed me how, without progressive wealth taxation, extreme wealth appropriation can worsen inequality
feedback_items.why_strong: Demonstrates engagement with high-level economic theory and ability to extract meaningful insights rather than just summarizing.

feedback_items.your_feedback: I don't want to give more advice because it would take away from your authentic voice. The things generally corrected in others - theory, repetitiveness, logical flow, lack of insights - you have none of those issues.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Keep the authentic voice rather than over-editing.

feedback_items.your_feedback: It doesn't look like you've got an essay written for additional submissions. Let me know what college you're applying to at Cambridge and what you plan to submit.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Prepare for interview questions and review any additional submissions required by your Cambridge college.

feedback_items.your_feedback: You should really consider Imperial economics as well. You've got KCL in there, so London doesn't seem to be an issue.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Consider adding Imperial to your choices if location isn't a concern.

feedback_items.your_feedback: I would be shocked if you didn't get an interview for Cambridge.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Focus on interview preparation as next step.

subject: Economics and Economic History
statement_full_text:
Why do you want to study this course or subject?

The integration of economic theory with historical contexts has provided a quantitative and qualitative lens of the progress of global economic history and development. This approach excites me since it offers a holistic understanding of the uncertainties of the past in their own right, as well as aiding economic policy and management decisions for the issues we face today.

How have your qualifications and studies helped you to prepare for this course or subject?

As cofounder of the Economics Society, I led research on a group entry to Discover Economics' essay competition in which I explored the drivers of UK wealth inequality and ways they can be addressed. We concluded that unequal opportunities to asset ownership, regional investment and financial literacy is the driver. We honed in on the failure of the Right to Buy Scheme and unequal regional benefits of globalisation to explain how unequal access to the property ladder and post-industrial regions' structural decline has driven UK wealth inequality. Amongst policies like wealth and exodus taxes, we suggested that investment in education and financial literacy in deprived areas is pivotal to improving wealth inequality and economic development. Thus, when reading 'Global Economic History' (R.C. Allen) I agreed that the use of universal education was the most effective 'standard model' development strategy that helped Northwestern Europe and the USA catch up to Britain's industrial comparative advantage. In 'The Bottom Billion' (Collier), I concur with the view that the poorest countries require more than just simple international aid to escape the poverty trap. Instead, targeted aid,peacekeeping and investment are necessary. Allen also voiced how investment banks providing firms with capital was another standard model strategy for industrial development. This inspired me to research more into the role of investment banks and analyse whether the deregulation of such financial institutions in the 1980s led to the 2008 financial crisis. The article 'Reagan Did it' (P.Krugman) explored the notion that the incentive for high risks by deregulating was to blame for 2008. This clarified to me that 1980s neoliberal reform left economies vulnerable. My CISI exams motivate me to explore financial regulation and ethics. In 'Can there be another Crash?', Heller examined causes of the Great Depression and compared them with the economic climate of the late 1970s. Whilst he incorrectly concluded that another crash was unlikely, I appreciated that Heller was taking a historical perspective on the study of economics and making future predictions. However, this presented me with the danger that making too many parallels with the present when analysing the past can lead to inaccuracies. Economic history should be analysed to understand past economic phenomena, not solely to predict the future. I was thus prompted to attend an LSE economic history lecture on the convergent evolution of monetary systems. I was fascinated by the process by which Germany formed its first common currency - proven necessary due to Gresham's Law ('bad money' drove out 'good money' - Kreuzers).

What else have you done to prepare outside of education, and why are these experiences useful?

In a Balliol College tutorial, I applied game theory strategies in problem-solving exercises and in a QMUL taster I explored how mathematics like calculus can be applied to economics through utility functions. This furthered my motivation to study economics through a quantitative and qualitative lens. 'Factfulness' (Rosling) challenged my personal biases and refined my data interpretation. I enjoyed its criticism of sensationalism and promotion of a fact based world view, though I question how some negative trend topics like ecological sustainability were refrained from. During my F1 work experience, I took on the role of all executive business roles. This made me reflect on a sustainable operations lecture, which emphasised the need for constant consideration of ESG goals when making decisions like where the next Grand Prix should be. Overall, these experiences have shaped my desire to study degree level economics.

feedback_items.weak_passage: your personal statement sounds like a list
feedback_items.your_feedback: Your concern that the statement sounds like a list is very self-aware and correct. You're not allowing yourself to develop points in any meaningful way. It's not leveled enough.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Develop each point more thoroughly rather than listing multiple superficial points. Build up good separate sections even if they don't flow perfectly together.

feedback_items.weak_passage: the insights that you're pulling out from these books are not the best insights you could pull out
feedback_items.your_feedback: The insights you're pulling from books are basically the blurb - you could get them from Wikipedia. This doesn't prove you can read, comprehend, analyze, and work with high-level texts to make points.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Extract deeper, more analytical insights from the books you've read. Show you can engage with complex ideas, not just summarize them.

feedback_items.weak_passage: The integration of economic theory with historical contexts has provided a quantitative and qualitative lens of the progress of global economic history and development.
feedback_items.your_feedback: Too vague, not talking about anything specific. It's hard to understand what you mean - it's up to interpretation. You're just saying economics and history is interesting because it shows us what's happened over time, but you've overcomplicated it.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Simplify and clarify. Either make it more concise or add a specific example that reinforces your point. Avoid general sentences without concrete examples.

feedback_items.weak_passage: This approach excites me since it offers a holistic understanding of the uncertainties of the past in their own right, as well as aiding economic policy and management decisions
feedback_items.your_feedback: Even more vague. What uncertainties? How does it aid economic policy? What's the link? It sounds like you're trying to shove in economics, history, and management so anyone reading will think you're talking about their subject.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Be specific about what uncertainties you mean and clearly explain the connection between historical understanding and policy. Don't just name-drop subjects.

feedback_items.weak_passage: We concluded that unequal opportunities to asset ownership, regional investment and financial literacy is the driver.
feedback_items.your_feedback: This conclusion only makes sense if you have qualifiers in front of the items. As written, it doesn't make sense grammatically or logically.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Rephrase: 'We found these drivers to be unequal opportunity for asset ownership, uneven distribution of regional investment, and poor financial literacy.' Use semicolons to show connections between sentences.

feedback_items.weak_passage: We honed in on the failure of the right to buy scheme and unequal regional benefits of globalisation to explain how unequal access to the property ladder and post-industrial regions structural decline has driven UK wealth inequality.
feedback_items.your_feedback: You're bringing in too much stuff without focus. You have right to buy scheme, regional benefits of globalization, property ladder access, and post-industrial decline - all unsubstantiated and not developed. It's better to focus on one topic deeply.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Choose one topic (either right to buy scheme OR post-industrial decline) and develop it thoroughly with evidence and facts. For example, explain specifically how the right to buy scheme affected people with poor financial literacy.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Thus, when reading 'Global Economic History' (R.C. Allen) I agreed that the use of universal education was the most effective 'standard model' development strategy
feedback_items.your_feedback: Not clear what you mean by universal education - state-led free education? School or financial literacy? The connection to your previous point about financial literacy is invisible. Also, why bring in Northwest Europe and USA when discussing UK inequality?
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Clarify what type of education you mean and make explicit connections to your previous arguments about UK inequality. Ensure geographic comparisons are relevant.

feedback_items.weak_passage: In 'The Bottom Billion' (Collier), I concur with the view that the poorest countries require more than just simple international aid to escape the poverty trap. Instead, targeted aid,peacekeeping and investment are necessary.
feedback_items.your_feedback: This is almost a 'yeah, obviously' point. Of course aid by itself isn't enough. The real question is whether aid is damaging or constrains growth. Your insight here is unsubstantiated and doesn't show deep engagement with the book.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Engage with more nuanced questions about aid effectiveness and potential negative impacts. Show critical thinking rather than agreeing with obvious points.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Allen also voiced how investment banks providing firms with capital was another standard model strategy for industrial development.
feedback_items.your_feedback: This sounds like just a fact - 'the sky is blue' level. How does this pertain to the argument you're trying to make? You suddenly jump to investment banks without clear connection.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Remove obvious factual statements that don't advance an argument. Create clear logical connections between topics rather than jumping around.

feedback_items.weak_passage: This inspired me to research more into the role of investment banks and analyse whether the deregulation of such financial institutions in the 1980s led to the 2008 financial crisis. The article 'Reagan Did it' (P.Krugman) explored the notion that the incentive for high risks by deregulating was to blame for 2008.
feedback_items.your_feedback: This is backwards. It doesn't make sense that you had the thought about deregulation and then Krugman confirmed it. You learned it from Krugman. Should say: 'In exploring 2008, I came across Krugman's suggestion that risk-taking incentivized by deregulation was one of the causes.'
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Present your learning chronologically and logically. Start with the source (Krugman) that gave you the idea, then discuss your analysis of it.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Whilst he incorrectly concluded that another crash was unlikely, I appreciated that Heller was taking a historical perspective on the study of economics and making future predictions.
feedback_items.your_feedback: This is not really an insight. The economy works in booms and busts, so there will be continual crashes. The interesting questions are about crash size, causes, mitigation, and knock-on impacts. You shouldn't be critiquing academics when neither of us are experts in the field.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Remove this critique. Focus on more substantive economic questions rather than obvious points about cyclical crashes. Don't position yourself as critiquing established academics.

feedback_items.weak_passage: However, this presented me with the danger that making too many parallels with the present when analysing the past can lead to inaccuracies. Economic history should be analysed to understand past economic phenomena, not solely to predict the future.
feedback_items.your_feedback: This is what I would call a red flag. Without a clear point you're making, this type of sentence is pointless and raises concerns about your understanding.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Remove these sentences entirely. They don't add value and could raise red flags for admissions tutors.

feedback_items.weak_passage: the last bit is actually, you know, it's, it's a random list of stuff
feedback_items.your_feedback: The final section is a random list, but there's a lot of interesting content here. Not sure why you haven't used these supercurriculars as starting points. The Balliol game theory and utility functions could tie in well with Factfulness data interpretation.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Use supercurriculars as foundations for developed sections. Start with the game theory problem, discuss the maths, bring in stats/data interpretation from Factfulness, then apply to a real case like the Krugman financial crisis analysis.

feedback_items.your_feedback: You're trying too hard to create a flowing narrative instead of building good separate sections. It doesn't matter if sections don't play well together. Just have clear, well-developed sections.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Restructure into clear sections: (1) Essay discussion with developed argument, (2) Mathematical economics section starting with utility functions/game theory, (3) Application of economics to real scenarios. Consider bringing in more mathematical content for LSE and ENM applications.

feedback_items.your_feedback: You should include more mathematical economic content, especially for LSE and ENM. For ENM, the mathematical econ will cover for you having no management content. For LSE, you study econ as much as history and that will play well.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Develop the game theory and utility function content more thoroughly. This could become a strong mathematical economics section that works well for all your applications.

feedback_items.your_feedback: I think it's a shame because you've done all the work and reading, but it's not coming across the way you want it to. If you don't want to make all the changes, at least change the language where it doesn't logically flow from one sentence to the next.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Consider substantial revisions to improve logical flow and development. At minimum, fix sentences that don't connect logically. You can resubmit for further feedback as a premium student.

feedback_items.your_feedback: TSA is going to carry you 90% of the way for ENM application. Make sure you're in the TSA workshops.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Prioritize TSA preparation and workshops alongside personal statement revision.

subject: Economics and Economic History
statement_full_text:
Why do you want to study this course or subject?

The integration of economic theory with historical contexts has provided a quantitative and qualitative lens on global economic progress and phenomena. As cofounder of the Economics Society, I delivered a presentation on financial institutions and this sparked my interest in researching the role of investment banks in the global economy. The article 'Reagan Did it' (P.Krugman) explored the notion that the incentive for high risks by deregulating was to blame for the 2008 Financial Crisis. This clarified to me that 1980s neoliberal reform left economies vulnerable. Thus, I believe that we must tightly regulate financial services (including shadow banking, credit raters and new fintech firms) to mitigate risk of financial sector induced global recessions. My CISI exams motivate me to explore financial regulation and ethics further. In 'Can there be another Crash?', Heller examines Great Depression causes in comparison with the economic climate of the late 1970s. Whilst he incorrectly concluded that another big crash was unlikely, I appreciated that Heller was taking a historical perspective on the study of economics and making future predictions. However, this presented me with the danger that making too many parallels with the present when analysing the past can lead to inaccuracies. Economic history should be analysed to understand past economic phenomena, not solely to predict the future. Using Cauchy distributions would be more appropriate for financial market predictions. In a Balliol College tutorial, I applied game theory strategies to pay-off matrices, applying interdependent decision making e.g between oligopolistic banks. Then, I explored utility functions and calculus. This furthered my motivation to study economics through a quantitative and qualitative lens.

How have your qualifications and studies helped you to prepare for this course or subject?

In my Discover Economics' essay competition, I explored the different drivers of persistent wealth inequality in the UK and the ways they can be addressed; I found the drivers to be unequal opportunities to: asset ownership, regional investment and financial literacy. I honed in on the failure of the Right to Buy Scheme to explain how unequal access to the property ladder has driven UK wealth inequality. It turned public assets into appreciating private wealth. Though, due to uneven regional benefits of globalisation like FDI there were disparities in appreciation. My calculations of house prices in the South growing by 1100% more than houses in the North showed to me the importance of that investment, especially considering post-industrial regions' structural decline. Analysing these statistics and Lorenz curves informed my conclusion. Amongst policies like wealth and exodus taxes, I argued that investment in education and financial literacy in deprived areas is pivotal to improving wealth inequality and lead to economic growth. This was inspired by R.C. Allen in 'Global Economic History' where I agreed that the use of universal education was the most effective 'standard model' development strategy that helped Northwestern Europe and the USA catch up to Britain's industrial comparative advantage. I believe that improving human capital is a development strategy that stands the test of time. Exploration of globalisation prompted me to attend an LSE economic history lecture on the convergent evolution of monetary systems. It made me wonder whether the rise of cryptocurrencies represents a modern form of evolutionary monetary convergence. Moreover, I was fascinated by the process by which Germany formed its first common currency union- proven necessary due to Gresham's Law ('bad money' drove out 'good money').

What else have you done to prepare outside of education, and why are these experiences useful?

During my F1 work experience, I took on the role of all executive business roles. This made me reflect on a sustainable operations lecture, which emphasised the need for constant consideration of ESG goals when making decisions like where the next Grand Prix should be. Overall, these experiences have shaped my readiness for undergraduate level economics.

feedback_items.weak_passage: The integration of economic theory with historical contexts has provided a quantitative and qualitative lens on global economic progress and phenomena.
feedback_items.your_feedback: Slightly vague opening. If you need more characters, remove this later. For now understandable if you want to keep it.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Consider removing if character count is tight, as it doesn't add significant value.

feedback_items.weak_passage: As cofounder of the Economics Society, I delivered a presentation on financial institutions and this sparked my interest in researching the role of investment banks
feedback_items.your_feedback: Can you be clearer on what the presentation was about? Too vague currently.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Suggested revision: 'As cofounder of my school's economics society, I delivered a presentation on reasons for the failure of [x y z institutions]; in doing this, I found the [x] role investment banks play in the global economy'

feedback_items.weak_passage: The article 'Reagan Did it' (P.Krugman) explored the notion that the incentive for high risks by deregulating was to blame for the 2008 Financial Crisis.
feedback_items.your_feedback: Phrasing needs improvement for clarity.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Rephrase: 'Krugman's article "Reagan Did It" explored the notion that deregulation of [x] incentivised risk-taking [in] and played a role in the 2008 Financial Crisis.'

feedback_items.weak_passage: This clarified to me that 1980s neoliberal reform left economies vulnerable.
feedback_items.your_feedback: This could just be absorbed into the previous sentence.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Combine with previous sentence for better flow and efficiency.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Thus, I believe that we must tightly regulate financial services (including shadow banking, credit raters and new fintech firms) to mitigate risk of financial sector induced global recessions.
feedback_items.your_feedback: Maybe you could say what new regulations have been brought in? Otherwise this is just your belief without backing.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Add evidence or examples of actual regulations to support your claim rather than just stating a belief.

feedback_items.weak_passage: My CISI exams motivate me to explore financial regulation and ethics further. In 'Can there be another Crash?', Heller examines Great Depression causes in comparison with the economic climate of the late 1970s.
feedback_items.your_feedback: Not super clear. The connection between CISI exams and Heller's book is unclear.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Suggested revision: 'For my CISI exams, I studied financial regulation and ethics in more detail. Heller's "Can there be another Crash?" examined causes of the Great Depression and how the economic climate at the time compared to that of the late 1970s.' Then cut down after clarifying.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Whilst he incorrectly concluded that another big crash was unlikely, I appreciated that Heller was taking a historical perspective
feedback_items.your_feedback: Not super clear what you mean by appreciating the historical perspective. Can you change your conclusion?
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Rephrase: 'Although his prediction for another big crash proved untrue, I found it an interesting [...]' Be more specific about what you found interesting.

feedback_items.weak_passage: However, this presented me with the danger that making too many parallels with the present when analysing the past can lead to inaccuracies.
feedback_items.your_feedback: This is nicer than previous statement, but maybe put this into the previous sentence to avoid repetition.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Combine with previous sentence for better flow.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Economic history should be analysed to understand past economic phenomena, not solely to predict the future.
feedback_items.your_feedback: Potentially add 'I appreciate that' at the start, then cut out 'solely to predict the future' since you've already made this clear.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Rephrase: 'I appreciate that economic history can help us understand past economic phenomena.' Remove redundant ending.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Using Cauchy distributions would be more appropriate for financial market predictions.
feedback_items.your_feedback: Why's that? Can you expand one or two sentences? It's interesting but sounds like name-dropping right now.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Add explanation of why Cauchy distributions are more appropriate. This could be a strong technical point if developed properly.

feedback_items.weak_passage: In a Balliol College tutorial, I applied game theory strategies to pay-off matrices, applying interdependent decision making e.g between oligopolistic banks. Then, I explored utility functions and calculus.
feedback_items.your_feedback: Interesting content - could be a strong part but can you explain more? 'Just exploring utility functions and calculus' sounds like 'exploring numbers and graphs' if you see what I mean. This section hasn't been seen much in other statements!
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Expand significantly on what you actually did and learned. This is unique content that deserves more development rather than just being listed.
feedback_items.strong_passage: game theory strategies to pay-off matrices, applying interdependent decision making e.g between oligopolistic banks
feedback_items.why_strong: Good section with unique content not commonly seen in other statements. Has potential to be very strong if developed properly.

feedback_items.weak_passage: This furthered my motivation to study economics through a quantitative and qualitative lens.
feedback_items.your_feedback: This is a repeat of the first sentence! Choose one location for this phrase.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Remove this repetition - you've already made this point in the opening.

feedback_items.your_feedback: Essay competition section is fine overall, no major issues.
feedback_items.strong_passage: In my Discover Economics' essay competition, I explored the different drivers of persistent wealth inequality in the UK
feedback_items.why_strong: Clear topic with good scope for development.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I honed in on the failure of the Right to Buy Scheme to explain how unequal access to the property ladder has driven UK wealth inequality. It turned public assets into appreciating private wealth.
feedback_items.your_feedback: Maybe rephrase to make clear it was a failure for that specific reason you've pointed out, not a categorical failure overall. It's slightly more controversial than that.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Clarify the nuance - the scheme wasn't universally a failure, but failed in this specific aspect.

feedback_items.weak_passage: My calculations of house prices in the South growing by 1100% more than houses in the North showed to me the importance of that investment
feedback_items.your_feedback: Do you mean 1100% more or 11x times more? This needs clarification.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Suggested rephrase: 'I calculated the house prices in the South had grown [...] compared to the North; this shows the sheer impact investment can have, particularly following the structural decline in post-industrial regions.'

feedback_items.weak_passage: Analysing these statistics and Lorenz curves informed my conclusion. Amongst policies like wealth and exodus taxes, I argued that investment in education and financial literacy in deprived areas is pivotal
feedback_items.your_feedback: The Lorenz curves analysis needs expansion. What did the Lorenz curves show? This section needs more development.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Rephrase: 'Further analysis of [...] showed [...]; I then drew out Lorenz curves that showed [...]. I concluded that investment in education and improving financial literacy rates in deprived areas is pivotal in reducing wealth inequality alongside wealth and exodus taxes.' The economic growth connection is a random add-on.

feedback_items.weak_passage: This was inspired by R.C. Allen in 'Global Economic History' where I agreed that the use of universal education was the most effective 'standard model' development strategy
feedback_items.your_feedback: Awkward phrasing with 'this was inspired by.'
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Rephrase: 'I also found from R.C. Allen's "Global Economic History" that the use of universal education is the most effective 'standard model' development strategy that...'

feedback_items.weak_passage: I believe that improving human capital is a development strategy that stands the test of time.
feedback_items.your_feedback: Bit unnecessary - cut if you need more characters.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Remove this filler sentence.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Exploration of globalisation prompted me to attend an LSE economic history lecture on the convergent evolution of monetary systems.
feedback_items.your_feedback: Cut out 'exploration of globalisation prompted me to attend...' - just say 'I attended' which is fine.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Simplify: 'I attended an LSE economic history lecture...'

feedback_items.weak_passage: It made me wonder whether the rise of cryptocurrencies represents a modern form of evolutionary monetary convergence. Moreover, I was fascinated by the process by which Germany formed its first common currency union
feedback_items.your_feedback: These are both decent points but a bit rushed - could use a sentence or two in between and after to properly develop them.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Add more development and connection between these two interesting points about monetary systems.

feedback_items.weak_passage: During my F1 work experience, I took on the role of all executive business roles.
feedback_items.your_feedback: What does this mean? Potentially cut this unclear statement.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Suggested rephrase: 'During my F1 work experience, I saw how they considered ESG goals such as where the next Grand Prix should take place; I recalled...' The section's not the strongest overall.

subject: Economics
statement_full_text:
2. How have your qualifications and studies helped you to prepare for this course or subject?

Reading an article on Trump's proposal to deregulate control emissions, after removing the US from the Paris Agreement, led me to question who bears the cost of such decisions. This inspired me to attend a lecture on 'Geopolitics of Climate Change', which introduced me to climate migration as an inevitable result of climate change. While relocating communities vulnerable to climate change may be considered an economically viable adaptation strategy, I believe it is inequitable and more must be done to reduce global emissions. Watching the documentary Anote's Ark reinforced this view, as I reflected on how small islands like Kiribati contribute negligibly to emissions yet face existential threats- a stark example of climate injustice. Seeking solutions, I entered the Financial Times essay competition, where I explored market-based instruments in controlling pollution. I found that well-enforced tradable pollution permits can be efficient, offering incentives to adopt green technology without burdening firms' costs. The EU ETS has been a success but needs global commitment to prevent carbon leakages.

After reading 'Rethinking the Economics of Land and Housing' by Collins, I learnt how land value largely accounts for exorbitant house prices in London. I was intrigued by the critique of neoclassical economics for conflating land with capital, despite its fixed supply and inability to respond to demand except through rising prices. To delve deeper, I attended a lecture 'Exploring Residential Property Markets', learning more about house price determinants. As I was posed with the question of how a new metro affects house/rent prices, I connected Ricardo's theory of economic rent- land values rise not only from the landowner's efforts, but from surrounding investment leading to higher rents. My growing interest in housing led me to explore solutions to the Hong Kong housing crisis in my EPQ. I learnt how government land auctions inflate scarce land prices as a main source of government revenue. While recognising the fiscal need, I argued it should not outweigh adequate and affordable housing provision. I concluded that adaptive reuse of vacant industrial buildings- feasible given Hong Kong's post-1980s manufacturing decline- provides immediate relief with land reclamation to increase developable land. Drawing on Collin's view of land as a financial asset, I believe these measures must be coupled with vacancy taxes to curb speculation and ensure housing serves as shelter. Moreover, I explored a YouTube series using multivariate regression in hedonic pricing to assess how factors such as pollution influence property values. Studying Maths deepened my appreciation for statistical modelling as a tool to uncover what people value most in a home.

3. What else have you done to prepare outside of education, and why are these experiences useful?

In the Green Schools Challenge I was project lead, developing NoteCycle, a digital solution to reduce paper use and promote sustainability. Placing 2nd and presenting to businesses honed my public speaking. I am the youngest member of my Parish Council's editorial team, where I contribute to meetings and write articles on local development, including housing, published to 3000 homes. Witnessing our magazine foster local business growth and build a sense of place, fascinates me to explore regional development further at university. I am also fundraising to volunteer in South Africa next summer, eager to broaden my understanding of addressing inequality.

feedback_items.weak_passage: entire first paragraph
feedback_items.your_feedback: This entire first paragraph is definitely your weakest. It's just not the best opening in general. The difference between your first and second paragraphs is quite big - if I marked the second one a 7, the first would be a 4 or 5.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Consider completely reshaping this first paragraph or replacing it with stronger content. The NEA project might work better as question one content since it's a good project with specific examples and natural conclusions.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Reading an article on Trump's proposal to deregulate control emissions
feedback_items.your_feedback: Not sure if you're talking about an academic article or the news. If it's news, better to go straight in and say Trump proposed this and it led you to question it. If it's an academic article, you need to quote the actual writer.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Clarify whether this is news or academic literature. Either cite the author if academic, or jump straight into the topic if it's news coverage.

feedback_items.weak_passage: who bears the cost of such decisions
feedback_items.your_feedback: You question who bears the cost, but you don't address this question again. This is confusing because you raise it but don't follow through.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Either answer the question you pose or remove it. Every question raised should be addressed somewhere in the statement.

feedback_items.weak_passage: relocating communities vulnerable to climate change may be considered an economically viable adaptation strategy
feedback_items.your_feedback: Not entirely sure what you mean by this. If you mean it makes sense from an economics point of view, it just doesn't really mean anything as stated.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Clarify what you mean by economically viable and who considers it so. Be more specific about the economic argument.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I believe it is inequitable, and more must be done to reduce global emissions
feedback_items.your_feedback: This kind of sentence is confusing and buzz-wordy, like a politician. 'More must be done' doesn't mean anything specific. You either discuss that particular policy or a different policy, but you can't just say more must be done.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Replace vague statements with specific policy discussions or concrete suggestions. Avoid politician-style language.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Watching the documentary Anote's Ark
feedback_items.your_feedback: Documentary reference is fine but a bit random in the flow of the argument.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Better integrate the documentary into your argument rather than it appearing as a disconnected addition.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I found that well-enforced tradable pollution permits can be efficient
feedback_items.your_feedback: This is quite basic. Pollution permits can work, as can many other forms, as long as they're well-enforced. It doesn't sound smart, and looking at your other writing, you do sound smarter. This doesn't do you justice.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Dig deeper into the economics of tradable permits. Discuss specific conditions, trade-offs, or nuances that show sophisticated understanding.

feedback_items.weak_passage: The EU ETS has been a success but needs global commitment to prevent carbon leakages
feedback_items.your_feedback: This comes out of nowhere. The idea of success without quantifying or saying how it's been successful is not great. It's an opinion word - you need backing for something like that.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Define what makes it a success with specific metrics or evidence. Explain the carbon leakage concern with more detail.

feedback_items.your_feedback: This whole second paragraph works pretty well as a whole. The critique of neoclassical economics for conflating land with capital is pretty interesting.
feedback_items.strong_passage: I was intrigued by the critique of neoclassical economics for conflating land with capital, despite its fixed supply and inability to respond to demand except through rising prices
feedback_items.why_strong: Shows engagement with sophisticated economic theory and demonstrates critical thinking about established frameworks.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I learnt how land value largely accounts for exorbitant house prices in London
feedback_items.your_feedback: First sentence is a little bit obvious. Not the end of the world, not bad, but somewhat basic.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Consider starting with a less obvious insight from the book, or add a more nuanced element to this statement.

feedback_items.weak_passage: It all leads and connects quite nicely
feedback_items.your_feedback: The flow and connections in this paragraph work well. Ricardo's theory connects naturally to the lecture content.
feedback_items.strong_passage: As I was posed with the question of how a new metro affects house/rent prices, I connected Ricardo's theory of economic rent- land values rise not only from the landowner's efforts, but from surrounding investment leading to higher rents
feedback_items.why_strong: Good application of economic theory to a practical question, showing ability to make connections.

feedback_items.weak_passage: studying math deepen my appreciation for statistical modelling as a tool
feedback_items.your_feedback: Don't capitalize subjects like maths - only languages need capitalization. Rather than this sentence about appreciation, it would be more interesting to expand on what you actually did or what mathematical modeling skills you picked up in the YouTube series.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Explain the actual mathematical techniques you learned and how you applied them. Maths content is a huge part of economics and they'll appreciate detailed discussion of mathematical skills.

feedback_items.your_feedback: The Ricardo content is basic but it's a good connection to what you were talking about. The positioning of how you came about learning that information, then going into more basic stuff, then connecting upwards works well.
feedback_items.strong_passage: I connected Ricardo's theory of economic rent- land values rise not only from the landowner's efforts, but from surrounding investment
feedback_items.why_strong: Appropriate level of theory for the context, well-integrated into the narrative.

feedback_items.your_feedback: If you want to make this more high level, expand on the maths part - the YouTube series and statistical modeling content.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Add more detail about the mathematical techniques used in hedonic pricing and multivariate regression. This would strengthen the section significantly.

feedback_items.your_feedback: Last paragraph is generally OK. If you need to cut characters, the logical place would be to reduce material here, but if you can keep it, there's no problem with it. It's all good stuff.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Keep as is unless character count requires cuts, in which case this section could be trimmed.

feedback_items.your_feedback: Overall this is not a bad statement - this is a good statement overall. It's just if you had something else you could bring in or reshape that first paragraph, it would be quite a lot stronger.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Focus revision efforts on completely reworking the first paragraph. Consider using the NEA content as your question one material since it's a strong project with specific examples.

feedback_items.your_feedback: LSE puts a lot of emphasis on maths. They love anything statistics, anything super quant. If you have things you can expand in that area, that's better.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Expand mathematical and quantitative content, particularly the statistical modeling section. This will play well for LSE applications.

feedback_items.your_feedback: Not a fan of making question one too personal - bringing up your experience of seeing things is clichÃ© and not always authentic. Better to go straight into it: I read this book, I find this subject area interesting. Development economics is fine to talk about, not many people discuss it.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: For question one, consider using your NEA project since it's a good project with specific examples and natural conclusions. Avoid overly personal opening narratives.

subject: Geography and Economics
statement_full_text:
1. Why do you want to study this course or subject?

Growing up in a small town, I have always viewed cities as areas of success and opportunity. Intrigued if this perception was true, I turned to Glaeser's book 'Triumph of the City', where I was captivated by the story of Detroit's decline revealing that not all cities emulate this ideal. I reflected on how clustering of firms can drive innovation and economic growth, and think the most important agglomeration economies for Detroit are knowledge spillovers. Detroit's decline was multilayered, but I believe its main weakness was its inability to address the diminishing human capital that automotive assembly line production created, by reducing the need for cities to spread knowledge. This piqued my interest in urban economics and led me to dedicate my NEA on how the quality of life differs between two estates in Milton Keynes. I explored wealth distribution, using Spearman's rank to test the association between house prices and house area, and discovered that Beanhill had substantially cheaper housing than Shenley Church End. Beanhill was a centre of extreme deprivation, allowing me to see parallels with Glaeser's argument that cheap housing often attracts the poor. The desire to understand how urban growth interacts with the housing market motivates me to study Geography and Economics.

2. How have your qualifications and studies helped you to prepare for this course or subject?

After reading 'Rethinking the Economics of Land and Housing' by Collins, I learnt how land value largely accounts for exorbitant house prices. I was intrigued by the critique of neoclassical economics for conflating land with capital, despite its fixed supply and inability to respond to demand except through rising prices. To delve deeper, I attended a lecture by the University of Cambridge 'Exploring Residential Property Markets', where I learnt more about determinants of house prices. As I was posed with the question of how a new metro affects house or rent prices, I connected Ricardo and Smith's theory of economic rent - land values rise not only from the landowner's efforts, but from surrounding investment leading to higher rents. My growing interest in housing led me to explore solutions to the Hong Kong housing crisis in my EPQ. I reflected on how government land auctions inflate scarce land prices as a main source of government revenue. While recognising the fiscal need, I argued it should not outweigh adequate and affordable housing provision. I concluded that adaptive reuse of vacant industrial buildings, feasible given Hong Kong's post-1980s manufacturing decline, provides immediate relief with land reclamation to increase developable land. Drawing on Collin's view of land as a financial asset, I believe these measures must be coupled with vacancy taxes to curb speculation and ensure housing serves as shelter.

Visiting my grandad who farmed the land in Kalampatti, a small village in India, I became aware of how closely people's livelihoods depend on the natural environment. This inspired me to watch Sukhdev's TED Talk 'Put a Value on Nature', where I discovered that the world is irretrievably losing natural capital at a rapid rate of $2-4 trillion annually due to the economic invisibility of nature. To explore how to address this, I attended a lecture by the University of Cambridge on 'Valuing Nature: Why and How?', where I learnt about how non-market valuation methods can incentivise conserving nature by assigning a monetary value for ecosystem services. The Exxon Valdez oil spill in 1998 is an example of how contingent valuation was used to assess the American public's willingness to pay to prevent another similar accident. However, I believe the value produced is not fully reliable, since contingent valuation introduces hypothetical bias as actual payments may differ from stated ones. I found revealed preference methods, such as replacement cost, more convincing, as they monetise ecosystem services by using real market behaviour through equating them with the manual cost that farmers like my grandad would otherwise incur for processes like pollination. Therefore, I think valuation is most useful when applied pragmatically in public spending decisions, as recognised in the UK's Green Book for cost-benefit analysis to ensure natural capital is accounted for.

3. What else have you done to prepare outside of education, and why are these experiences useful?

Beyond studies, I led my team in the Green Schools Challenge, where we placed 2nd with our proposal of NoteCycle, a digital solution to target excessive paper use and promote sustainability. Being the youngest member of my Parish Council's editorial team, I write articles that are published to 3000 homes and contribute to discussions about the development of our community. Engaging with different perspectives on issues such as housing has taught me to consider multiple stakeholders when evaluating policies at the intersection of Geography and Economics.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Growing up in a small town, I have always viewed cities as areas of success and opportunity. Intrigued if this perception was true, I turned to Glaeser's book 'Triumph of the City', where I was captivated by the story of Detroit's decline revealing that not all cities emulate this ideal.
feedback_items.your_feedback: Nice opening but needs rephrasing. Triumph of the City is mostly about celebrating urbanization, so some sections need adjustment. Also 'this ideal' is unclear - what ideal are you referring to?
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Suggested revision: 'Growing up in a small town, I had always viewed cities as meccas for success and opportunity; however, reading the cautionary tale of Detroit's decline in Glaeser's "Triumph of the City" showed me that success is not guaranteed and that x, y, z is needed to facilitate... etc.' Rephrase or remove 'the ideal.' This version shows more development and lets you pack in more content.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I reflected on how clustering of firms can drive innovation and economic growth, and think the most important agglomeration economies for Detroit are knowledge spillovers.
feedback_items.your_feedback: What do you mean 'reflected'? Not really a topic to reflect on - are you drawing a conclusion? Why did you reflect and decide this? What's the relationship between clustering of firms and your point about Detroit? Weak sentence because of the 'reflected' and the 'think' repetition/uncertainty. Unsupported conclusion - based on what? What do you even mean by knowledge spillovers in Detroit's context? And from where?
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Remove vague language like 'reflected' and 'think.' Provide evidence for your conclusion about knowledge spillovers. Clarify what you mean by knowledge spillovers in Detroit's specific context.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Detroit's decline was multilayered, but I believe its main weakness was its inability to address the diminishing human capital that automotive assembly line production created, by reducing the need for cities to spread knowledge.
feedback_items.your_feedback: What do you mean 'multilayered'? Are you going to tell me what the layers are? Why was it multilayered? Don't use vague language without explaining. Why do you 'believe' the main weakness is diminishing human capital? Sounds like you just picked a random story from the book. The logic is actually wrong here - 'by reducing the need for cities to spread knowledge' makes no sense! It reads like you're relying on the reader to know the book and fill in gaps.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Correct the logic: 'The increase in automotive production = diminishing need for human capital = declining skills + increase in automotive production = less need for knowledge spillover = weaker city.' Stop relying on the reader to fill gaps. Explain your reasoning clearly.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I explored wealth distribution, using Spearman's rank to test the association between house prices and house area, and discovered that Beanhill had substantially cheaper housing than Shenley Church End. Beanhill was a centre of extreme deprivation, allowing me to see parallels with Glaeser's argument that cheap housing often attracts the poor.
feedback_items.your_feedback: This is very A Level knowledge. Spearman's doesn't give much springboard to link to interesting concepts. Also quite descriptive writing - I explored x, I used y, and found that z. No critical analysis, no higher level development. Then the Glaeser 'argument' (not really an argument because of course cheap housing attracts lower income individuals) is shoved in without adding anything. What parallels could you really be seeing there? The cheap housing = less wealthy conclusion is much too obvious.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: What conclusions did you find during the NEA? Surely you were exploring something beyond just finding that some areas are more deprived than others? The cheap housing point is too obvious. Focus on more sophisticated conclusions from your research.

feedback_items.weak_passage: The desire to understand how urban growth interacts with the housing market motivates me to study Geography and Economics.
feedback_items.your_feedback: Filler but fine.

feedback_items.weak_passage: After reading 'Rethinking the Economics of Land and Housing' by Collins, I learnt how land value largely accounts for exorbitant house prices.
feedback_items.your_feedback: Again, quite an obvious conclusion. Surely land value = higher house prices - anyone could tell you this without reading Ryan-Collins' book. You should try to summarize the main conclusion from the book. You got the author name wrong btw - it's Ryan-Collins.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Focus on the book's main argument rather than obvious points. Correct author name to Ryan-Collins. Extract a more sophisticated insight.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I was intrigued by the critique of neoclassical economics for conflating land with capital, despite its fixed supply and inability to respond to demand except through rising prices.
feedback_items.your_feedback: I get what you're trying to say but you need to explain this better. And you need an actual conclusion.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Suggested revision: 'Economic theorists have conflated land with capital; Ryan-Collins argues that land should be treated as a separate factor of production because unlike capital, land is in fixed supply and generates location-based rents...' Then link this to what impacts/implications this has for society that interests you.

feedback_items.weak_passage: To delve deeper, I attended a lecture by the University of Cambridge 'Exploring Residential Property Markets', where I learnt more about determinants of house prices.
feedback_items.your_feedback: You shouldn't just name-drop. Tell me what you learned about the determinants of house prices. Not clear what you're delving deeper into because you haven't got a strong conclusion in previous sections.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Explain what you actually learned from the lecture about house price determinants. Build on a clear conclusion from the previous section.

feedback_items.weak_passage: As I was posed with the question of how a new metro affects house or rent prices, I connected Ricardo and Smith's theory of economic rent - land values rise not only from the landowner's efforts, but from surrounding investment leading to higher rents.
feedback_items.your_feedback: You need to finish sentences. 'Leading to higher rents' - why? 'Surrounding investment' is unclear - explain what everything means. The sentence needs better structure.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Change writing: 'When considering how new metro lines affect property values, I drew on Ricardo's theory of economic rent, that land values increase not just from landowners' improvements, but from external investments such as transport infrastructure, allowing landowners to capture higher rents from improved accessibility...' Explain the mechanism fully.

feedback_items.weak_passage: My growing interest in housing led me to explore solutions to the Hong Kong housing crisis in my EPQ. I reflected on how government land auctions inflate scarce land prices as a main source of government revenue. While recognising the fiscal need, I argued it should not outweigh adequate and affordable housing provision. I concluded that adaptive reuse of vacant industrial buildings, feasible given Hong Kong's post-1980s manufacturing decline, provides immediate relief with land reclamation to increase developable land.
feedback_items.your_feedback: Fine, not the best argument but standard, no red flags at least. Could use some source material to strengthen it.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Add source material to support your arguments about Hong Kong housing crisis. While acceptable, this could be strengthened with references.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Drawing on Collin's view of land as a financial asset, I believe these measures must be coupled with vacancy taxes to curb speculation and ensure housing serves as shelter.
feedback_items.your_feedback: Ryan-Collins, not Collin. This sounds like you're petitioning for a particular policy rather than an academic exploration of what causes the housing crisis and solutions for it.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Potentially rephrase: 'In the course of my research, I realised the importance for...' Make it sound more like academic analysis rather than personal advocacy.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Visiting my grandad who farmed the land in Kalampatti, a small village in India
feedback_items.your_feedback: Fine opening. You probably don't need to mention 'small village' - it's fine to just leave as place name.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Remove 'small village' as it's unnecessary detail.

feedback_items.weak_passage: This inspired me to watch Sukhdev's TED Talk 'Put a Value on Nature', where I discovered that the world is irretrievably losing natural capital
feedback_items.your_feedback: Try to avoid 'this inspired me to...' phrasing. Just say 'I watched...' In general, you are name-dropping a lot of sources without developing them - kind of a waste of characters tbh.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Remove 'this inspired me to' phrases. Develop the sources you mention rather than just listing them.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I attended a lecture by the University of Cambridge on 'Valuing Nature: Why and How?', where I learnt about how non-market valuation methods can incentivise conserving nature by assigning a monetary value for ecosystem services.
feedback_items.your_feedback: There is no subject here - who is being incentivised? You can't make this argument properly without identifying the players. 'Monetary value for ecosystem services' is not very clear phrasing.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Clarify who is being incentivized. Explain ecosystem services more clearly. Identify the stakeholders in your argument.

feedback_items.weak_passage: The Exxon Valdez oil spill in 1998 is an example of how contingent valuation was used to assess the American public's willingness to pay to prevent another similar accident. However, I believe the value produced is not fully reliable, since contingent valuation introduces hypothetical bias
feedback_items.your_feedback: We are jumping around a lot! When did we get into contingent valuation? Again with 'I believe' - based on what? Where is the evidence, how have you got to that conclusion? You can't make claims without explaining where you got the information and in what context.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Set up contingent valuation before jumping to the Exxon example. Provide evidence for your claims rather than just stating beliefs. Create logical transitions between topics.

feedback_items.weak_passage: I found revealed preference methods, such as replacement cost, more convincing, as they monetise ecosystem services by using real market behaviour through equating them with the manual cost that farmers like my grandad would otherwise incur for processes like pollination.
feedback_items.your_feedback: You can't find revealed preference methods more convincing without explaining where you got this information from and in what context. This is such a messy paragraph! Where are farmers coming from, and your grandad? The set-up for this is very weak and muddled.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Restructure this entire section. Set up the comparison between valuation methods properly. Connect back to your grandad organically rather than forcing it.

feedback_items.weak_passage: Therefore, I think valuation is most useful when applied pragmatically in public spending decisions, as recognised in the UK's Green Book for cost-benefit analysis to ensure natural capital is accounted for.
feedback_items.your_feedback: This is actually just out of left field now. Again thinking something without any evidence. And bringing in yet another source randomly with no setup or development.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Either remove this or properly set it up with preceding argument. Don't introduce new sources at the very end without development.

feedback_items.your_feedback: Third paragraph is fine - standard supercurricular content, no issues.
feedback_items.strong_passage: Being the youngest member of my Parish Council's editorial team, I write articles that are published to 3000 homes and contribute to discussions about the development of our community
feedback_items.why_strong: Good demonstration of engagement with community issues and stakeholder perspectives.

feedback_items.weak_passage: entire statement has repetition and name dropping throughout
feedback_items.your_feedback: As a whole, there's a lot of repetition. You're saying 'I believe,' 'I think' repeatedly. You're name-dropping lots of sources. Even if you just remove those things, you'd lose like 20% of your statement, showing how little actual information is in it. You jump around so much, there's a lack of development.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: If you have the time, make substantial changes. Remove repetitive phrases like 'I believe' and 'I think.' Stop name-dropping and develop sources properly. Create clear logical flow between ideas.

feedback_items.your_feedback: I've rewritten some sections for you but couldn't do everything. Look at the detailed feedback document and let me know what you feel able to change, what you have time for, and anything that doesn't make sense. As it stood, it was a little bit all over the place.
feedback_items.improvement_suggested: Review the detailed written feedback provided. Make as many changes as time permits, prioritizing the critical issues. You can resubmit for further review.
